dc:description: LDB3 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive dilated cardiomyopathy in 2023 (Koopmann et al, PMID: 36253531). In addition to DCM, LDB3 has also been reported with myofibrillar myopathy at the time of review. This was considered in accordance with ClinGen lumping and splitting criteria. Due to the distinct differences in phenotypic variability the curation was split and curated for AR DCM. LDB3 has also been curated by the ClinGen DCM GCEP for AD DCM. Human genetic evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data. At least four unique frameshift/truncation variants and one splice site have been reported in humans in homozygous or compound heterozygous state (Koopmann et al, PMID: 36253531). In addition, this gene-disease assertion is supported by expression studies, in vitro functional assays, protein interaction studies, and animal models. It has been well established LDB3 is expressed in the heart (Faulkner et al, 1999, PMID: 10427098, Zhou et al, 1999, PMID: 10391924, Huang et al, 2004, PMID: 12499364, Vatta et al, 2004, PMID: 4662268). Protein interaction studies show LDB3 interacts with ACTN2 (Faulker et al, 1999, PMID: 10427098, Zhou et al, 1999 PMID: 10391924, Zheng et al, 2009, PMID: 19028670, Zhou et al, 2001, PMID: 11696561) and TNNI3 (Lv et al, 2021, PMID: 34966794). Importantly, knockout animal models developed dilated cardiomyopathy and heart failure (Cheng et al., 2011, PMID: 21303826, Zhou et al, 2001, PMID: 11696561, Zheng et al., 2009, PMID: 19028670). Zebrafish and mouse animal rescue models showed injection of Cypher resulted in at least a partial rescue of the phenotype (Huang et al, 2004 PMID: 12499364, Van de Meer et al, 2006, PMID: 16982050). In summary, there is strong evidence to support the relationship between LDB3 and AR DCM. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on March 21, 2025 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Phenotype is not dilated cardiomyopathy
RNA analysis demonstrated little/no expression of LDB3 protein with a functional C-terminal LIM domain in muscle tissue from the affected fetus.
Phenotype is not dilated cardiomyopathy
RNA analysis demonstrated little/no expression of LDB3 protein with a functional C-terminal LIM domain in muscle tissue from the affected fetus.
Reduced due to consanguinity, default scoring for DCM GCEP is 1pt
Reduced due to consanguinity, default scoring for DCM GCEP is 1pt
Reduced due to consanguinity, default scoring for DCM GCEP is 1pt
Reduced due to presumed consanguinity (parents from the same "small village"), default scoring for DCM GCEP is 1pt

The phenotype observed in the knockdown zebrafish is not a robust version of DCM. Additionally, human data has shown a heterozygous phenotype while this experimental data is only for knockout of both alleles.
The ventricular thinning seen in the zebrafish embryos was stated as the authors as a similar sign of dilated cardiomyopathy in humans as the ventricle also thins.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish model

evidence.dc:description: This is building upon the original mouse model showing a stressor increases the timeline. It does not provide completely separate data for curation.

-KO mice developed an enlarged left ventricle in response to pressure-overload
-KO mice developed increased LV mass in response to isoproterenol

DCM phenotype developed faster with stressor present
evidence.rdfs:label: Stress-induced dilated cardiomyopathy in young CypherL KO

evidence.dc:description: Only the higher RNA dosage was noted to rescue the "DCM" phenotype and only a portion of these embryos were rescued.

caudal regression and somite disorganization was rescued in up to 85% of zebrafish injected with the 10 ng RNA amount. 81% of these embryos had the pericardial enlargement rescued. Pericardial enlargement was not mentioned for the 5 ng amount.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of the cypher knock-down phenotype in zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Knockout mice developed enlarged heart chambers with thinner chamber walls compared to controls. The mice progressed to develop heart failure and had reduced fractional shortening. They all passed away prematurely by 23 weeks of age.
evidence.rdfs:label: Knockout of Cardiac Specific Isoform Cypher

evidence.dc:description: Knockout mice developed dilated left and right ventricles with abnormal histology consistent with DCM.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cypher KO Mice

evidence.dc:description: Mice developed signs of dilated cardiomyopathy including dilated LV and RV chambers and reduced cardiac function
evidence.rdfs:label: Inducible Cypher knockout mice

evidence.dc:description: mice developed dilated left ventricles with thinning of the muscle walls. Fractional shortening and systolic function were also decreased. All mice with knockout long isoform passed away by 20 weeks. Histology of KO mice showed Z-disc disorganization.
evidence.rdfs:label: Deletion of Cypher Long Form leads to DCM in Mice

evidence.dc:description: Rescue experiment does rescue a small percentage of mice with the long isoform knock-in and half of mice with short isoform knock-in. It uses a knock-in with Cypher null mice which is not as significant as if it had been mice with the missense variant. The authors used the skeletal isoform, not the cardiac isoform. There is limited information regarding the cardiac phenotype. All mice did still have cardiac fibrosis.

-80% of Cypher3sKI died by 4 weeks
-50% of Cypher2SKI died by 4 weeks
-Surviving mice all had growth retardation and abnormal striated muscle histology. Cardiac fibrosis was seen in both groups, more severe in group with Cyper3SKI
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue Cypher null mice

evidence.dc:description: Protein Kinase C is not definitively associated with DCM
D626N variant increased the affinity of the LIM domain to protein kinase C
evidence.rdfs:label: p.Asp626Asn and Protein Kinase C

evidence.dc:description: Yeast two hybrid screen found 23 clones with fragments of the ACTN2 gene. The only other seven clones were false positives (mitochondrial genes and transcription factors).
evidence.rdfs:label: Yeast two hybrid screen ACTN2

evidence.dc:description: Analysis of RNA expression for isoforms revealed cardiac and skeletal muscle specific isoforms. This was confirmed using Western blot
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression cardiac and skeletal muscle isoforms

evidence.dc:description: The yeast two hybrid screen indicated cypher binds with alpha-actinin (ACTN2), myotilin (MYOT), and calsarcin-1 (MYOZ2). Deletion of the last residue in both MYOT and MYOZ2 impaired binding with cypher.
evidence.rdfs:label: Yeast two hybrid screen with MYOZ2, MYOT, ACTN2

evidence.dc:description: Northern blot analysis revealed LDB3 is expressed in the heart and skeletal muscle. Western blot analysis was also consistent with this finding.
evidence.rdfs:label: Northern and Western Blots

evidence.dc:description: Troponin I and its phosphorylation using neonatal heart lysates were detected by western blotting. Isoproterenol stimulation dramatically enhanced the phosphorylation of cTnI at Ser23/24 in the WT hearts. This effect was blunted in the hearts with Cypher ablation
evidence.rdfs:label: Downstream phosphorylation TNNI3

evidence.dc:description: The authors introduced mutations within the PDZ domain via PCR-based mutagenesis. "Mutant PDZ domains, and a control wild-type PDZ domain were fused to GST, and pull-down assays were performed to evaluate the interaction between mutant PDZ domains and -actinin 2. Mutation of either L76 or L80 to K significantly reduced binding of the Cypher PDZ domain to - actinin 2, and mutation of L78 to K completely abolished the binding." For part 2, the authors introduced mutations into the EF hands of ACTN2. "Results from GST pull down assays demonstrated that EF3–4, containing the last two EF hands, retained the ability to bind to the PDZ domain, whereas EF1–2, lacking the last two EF hands, 4EF-del3, and -actinin 2-del3, lacking only the last three amino acids, no longer bound the PDZ domain."
evidence.rdfs:label: Pull down assay

evidence.dc:description: Protein Kinase C is not definitively associated with DCM

Western blot analysis of immunoprecipitates of wild type or mutant Cypher (mouse model) along with HA-tagged Protein Kinase C (alpha, beta, and epsilon) showed wild type Cypher binds with protein kinase C.
evidence.rdfs:label: Pull down Assay Protein Kinase C

evidence.dc:description: Immunoprecipitation experiments showed ZASP is expressed in both fetal and adult hearts. Myosin was used as the control.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunoprecipitation ZASP

evidence.dc:description: Northern blot from human heart cells confirms expression of exons 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 10.
evidence.rdfs:label: Isoform expression in the human heart

evidence.dc:description: Co-immunoprecipitation showed binding between WT Cypher and ACTN2. Of note, the following variants in Cypher did not show any change in binding affinity with ACTN2 D117N, K136M, S189L, A165V, K204R/K251R, and R268C.
evidence.rdfs:label: Co-immunoprecipitation of ACTN2 with WT and variants

evidence.dc:description: Affimers to Z-disc protein domains in both control heart tissue and heart tissue of patients with DCM (secondary to TTN mutation)
evidence.rdfs:label: Affimers to Z-disc protein domains

evidence.dc:description: Protein Kinase C is not definitively implicated in a DCM mechanism
A yeast two-hybrid screen showed binding affinity between protein kinase C (alpha, epsilon, and zeta) and LDB3.
evidence.rdfs:label: Yeast two hybrid screen with Protein Kinase C

evidence.dc:description: semi-quantitative RT-PCR and whole mount in situ hybridization show Cypher expression in zebrafish heart and skeletal muscle
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish Expression

evidence.dc:description: PGM1 causes congenital disorder of glycosylation, not non-syndromic DCM
A co-IP assay confirmed interaction between PGM1 and ZASP/Cypher. Western blot analysis indicates binding with exon 4 in wild type cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunoprecipitation ZASP

evidence.dc:description: These two genes have not been definitively shown to be associated with DCM
In vivo immunoprecipitation of Cypher with calsarcin-1 and myotilin showing the interaction of Cypher with calsarcin-1 and myotilin through its PDZ domain
evidence.rdfs:label: immunoprecipitation MYOZ2 and MYOT

evidence.dc:description: PGM1 causes congenital disorder of glycosylation, not non-syndromic DCM
Two yeast hybrid screen revealed PGM1 interacts with LDB3.
evidence.rdfs:label: Yeast two hybrid screen with PGM1

evidence.dc:description: In situ hybridization revealed cypher is expressed in striated muscle tissues, including the myocardium, in mice embryos
evidence.rdfs:label: Cypher Expression in Mice embryos
